Arbitrary rules are at the heart of sport. Technology is problematic, partly because it would make it considerably more expensive and impractical to organise races, particularly in poorer countries.
However, the subjectivity of the rules is a problem. The thing is that race walking is thing that can be recognised but can't be perfectly described, so the technical definition is imperfect. There is a vague threshold where, to me, a small loss of contact is still race walking. As a result, there is inbuilt subjectivity and the flaws associated with that. Even worse is that the judges are not judged or really kept in line to try and limit subjectiveness.

The definition of "sport" is in no way arbitrary. It's simply an activity that multiple people participate in that has the following qualifications:
May (or may not) have rules. (unicycling)
May (or may not) be widely practiced. (fire dancing)
May (or may not) be considered a sport to many people. (chess)
May (or may not) be physically strenuous. (golf)
May (or may not) require physical activity. (planking)
May (or may not) be fun. (stinging nettle challenge)
See? It's simple.

The bans on tech, lying on the ground, etc. basically change that to "you can't run in too obvious a way."  And I feel that this breaks the sport.

sport
1. an athletic activity requiring skill or physical prowess and often of a competitive nature, as racing, baseball, tennis, golf, bowling, wrestling, boxing, hunting, fishing, etc.
2. a particular form of this, especially in the out of doors.
3. diversion; recreation; pleasant pastime.
4. jest; fun; mirth; pleasantry: What he said in sport was taken seriously.
5. mockery; ridicule; derision: They made sport of him.

athletics  (æθˈlɛtɪks) 
 
— n
1.	a. track and field events
 	b. ( as modifier ): an athletics meeting
2.	sports or exercises engaged in by athletes
3.	the theory or practice of athletic activities and training
